channel.title: FogSift — Knowledge Base
channel.description: Straight answers to complicated questions. Concepts, frameworks, tools, and field notes from FogSift.

item.title: Inversion
item.description: *Instead of asking how to succeed, ask what would guarantee failure — then avoid those things.*

item.title: The Adjacent Problem
item.description: *Organizations routinely solve the problem next to the real problem. The adjacent solution is easier to access, feels productive, and rarely fixes the thing tha

item.title: The Metric Mirage
item.description: A software company's key customer satisfaction metric improved for six consecutive quarters while customer churn quietly accelerated. This is a case study in ho

item.title: Base Rate Neglect
item.description: *When specific case information is available, people systematically underweight statistical background information — even when the background information is mor

item.title: The Proxy Trap
item.description: *When measuring the thing that matters is hard, we measure something easier instead. Then we optimize the proxy so aggressively that the original goal is forgot

item.title: Jobs To Be Done
item.description: Jobs To Be Done (JTBD) is a framework for understanding what people are actually trying to accomplish when they use a product, service, or process — and why the

item.title: Permission Debt
item.description: *Every approval required to get work done is either adding real value or incurring a tax on the organization's speed.*

item.title: The Halo Effect
item.description: *Our impression of a person in one domain contaminates our judgment of them in every other domain.*

item.title: The Hero Dependency
item.description: *Organizations that reward individual heroism are building fragility into their systems.*

item.title: Status Quo Bias
item.description: *The current state of affairs feels like the reference point against which all alternatives are measured — and alternatives are held to a higher standard than t

item.title: Availability Bias
item.description: *We judge probability by how easily examples come to mind — not by how often they actually occur.*

item.title: The Handoff Problem
item.description: *Every time ownership changes hands, something is lost.*

item.title: Anchoring Bias
item.description: *The first number in a conversation has disproportionate influence on all subsequent numbers in the conversation.*

item.title: Dunning-Kruger Effect
item.description: *The less you know, the more confident you are. The more you know, the more aware you are of what you don't know.*

item.title: Field Note 015: The Messenger Problem
item.description: *The problem isn't that leaders don't want bad news. They say they do. The problem is that every signal in the system punishes the delivery of it.*

item.title: Stakeholder Mapping
item.description: Stakeholder mapping is the systematic process of identifying everyone affected by or capable of affecting a project, decision, or change — then organizing them

item.title: Field Note 014: The Reorg Trap
item.description: *A reorganization is a decision to treat a structural problem as the cause of other problems. Sometimes that's right. Usually it's not.*

item.title: Regression to the Mean
item.description: *Extraordinary performance tends to be followed by ordinary performance, regardless of whether anything changed.*

item.title: Loss Aversion
item.description: *The pain of losing $100 is approximately twice as strong as the pleasure of gaining $100.*

item.title: Field Note 013: The Expertise Trap
item.description: *When you hire an expert, you're not just hiring their knowledge. You're hiring their pattern library — and the problems they don't see because those patterns d

item.title: Force Field Analysis
item.description: Force field analysis is a decision-making framework for understanding the forces that support and oppose a proposed change. Developed by psychologist Kurt Lewin

item.title: Confirmation Bias
item.description: *We don't seek information. We seek confirmation.*

item.title: Planning Fallacy
item.description: *We consistently underestimate how long things will take, how much they will cost, and how many things will go wrong — even when we know our past projects ran o

item.title: Field Note 012: Analysis Paralysis
item.description: *The danger isn't making a bad decision. The danger is making no decision until the moment forces one anyway — usually under worse conditions than if you'd deci

item.title: Goodhart's Law
item.description: *When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure.*

item.title: Pre-Mortem Analysis
item.description: A pre-mortem is a prospective failure analysis: before a project launches, you imagine it has already failed — then work backward to figure out why.

item.title: Field Note 011: Vanishing Context
item.description: *The most expensive thing that leaves when someone quits isn't their skills. It's what they knew that nobody wrote down.*

item.title: Case Study: The Data Migration Disaster
Case Study: The Startup That Wouldn't Pivot
Cognitive Biases
item.description: Cognitive biases are systematic patterns of deviation from rational judgment. They're mental shortcuts that usually help but sometimes mislead. Understanding th

item.title: Compounding Effects
item.description: Compounding is the process where small, consistent inputs produce disproportionately large outputs over time. It's the most powerful force in business, learning

item.title: First Principles Thinking
item.description: First principles thinking is the practice of breaking a problem down to its most fundamental truths and reasoning up from there, rather than reasoning by analog

item.title: Mental Models
item.description: Mental models are frameworks for understanding how things work. They simplify complex reality into patterns we can reason about. The quality of your thinking de

item.title: Opportunity Cost
item.description: Opportunity cost is the value of the next best alternative you give up when making a choice. Every "yes" is an implicit "no" to something else.

item.title: Root Cause Analysis
item.description: Root cause analysis is the systematic process of tracing a problem back to its origin. It's not about fixing symptoms. It's about finding the actual source.

item.title: Second-Order Effects
item.description: First-order effects are the direct, immediate consequences of an action. Second-order effects are the consequences of those consequences. Most strategic mistake

item.title: Signal vs Noise
item.description: Not all information is equal. Signal is information that tells you something true about reality. Noise is information that doesn't. The ability to distinguish b

item.title: Survivorship Bias
item.description: Survivorship bias is the logical error of concentrating on the people or things that made it past a selection process and overlooking those that did not. It lea

item.title: Systems Thinking
item.description: Systems thinking is a way of seeing the world as interconnected patterns rather than isolated events. It focuses on relationships, feedback, and emergence rathe

item.title: The Content Creation Pipeline
item.description: You have an idea. You want it to exist in the world. The distance between those two things is where most ideas go to die.

item.title: The Diagnostic Process
item.description: Every Fogsift engagement follows a consistent diagnostic process. The specific tools vary, but the structure remains the same.

item.title: Frequently Asked Questions

Constraint Mapping
item.description: Constraint mapping identifies and visualizes the boundaries within which a solution must operate. It prevents wasted effort on solutions that can't be implement

item.title: Decision Matrix
item.description: A decision matrix is a structured approach to evaluating options against weighted criteria. It turns complex decisions into transparent, defensible choices.

item.title: Feedback Loop Analysis
item.description: Feedback loops are circular chains of cause and effect where the output of a system influences its own input. Understanding them is essential for diagnosing per

item.title: Prioritization Matrix
item.description: A prioritization matrix helps you decide what to do first, what to do later, and what to not do at all. When everything feels urgent, the matrix reveals what ac

item.title: Risk Assessment
item.description: Risk assessment is the structured process of identifying what could go wrong, estimating how bad it would be, and deciding what to do about it. It's not about e

item.title: SWOT Analysis
item.description: SWOT is a strategic planning framework that evaluates a situation through four lenses: Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threats. Simple enough for a na

item.title: The TRACE Protocol
item.description: TRACE is our systematic approach to diagnostic investigation. It provides structure without being prescriptive, ensuring thorough investigation while remaining

item.title: Getting Started with Fogsift
item.description: Welcome to the Fogsift knowledge base. This wiki contains documentation, concepts, frameworks, and field notes from our consulting work.

item.title: How We Work
item.description: Fogsift operates differently from traditional consulting. We don't bring pre-packaged solutions. We bring diagnostic capability.

item.title: The Five Whys
item.description: The Five Whys is a simple but powerful technique for drilling past symptoms to find root causes. Ask "why?" repeatedly until you reach a cause you can actually

item.title: Pareto Analysis
item.description: Pareto Analysis applies the 80/20 rule to problem-solving: roughly 80% of effects come from 20% of causes. By identifying and focusing on the vital few, you get

item.description: Process mapping creates a visual representation of how work flows through a system. It reveals gaps, redundancies, bottlenecks, and opportunities for improvemen

item.title: Retrospective
item.description: A retrospective is a structured review of a completed period of work. It asks three questions: What went well? What didn't? What will we change? It's the simple
